alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for long-service awards
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing long-service awards
title: Expenses and benefits: long-service awards

table.body:
As an employer providing long-service awards to your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.


##What’s included

What you have to report and pay depends on:

* if the award is cash, non-cash or '[readily-convertible assets](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/payroll/special-pay/non-cash.htm "readily-convertible assets"){:rel="external"}' (RCAs), eg shares
* how much the award is for
* how long the employee has worked for you
* if you've given them a long-service award before

*[RCAs]:readily convertible assets
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report or pay on a non-cash award to an employee if all of the following apply:

* they've worked for you for at least 20 years
* the award is worth less than £50 per year of service
* you haven't given them a long-service award in the last 10 years

^For example, you can give a non-cash award with a value of up to £1,000 for 20 years' service.^

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What’s exempt

table.body:
If any of the long-service awards you provide aren’t exempt, you must report the costs to HMRC and deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on them.

##Cash awards

Any cash you award to an employee counts as part of their earnings. You must:

* add this amount to your employee’s other earnings
* deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance and PAYE tax through payroll

##Non-cash awards

For employees with at least 20 years service and no previous award in the last 10 years:

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | - 
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year  | Report on form P9D, section A(2) | Nothing
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section A | Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the award over £50 per year of service
Directors | Report on form P11D, section A | Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the award over £50 per year of service

For all other employees:

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year  | Report on form P9D, section A(2) | Nothing
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section A | Class 1A National Insurance on the full value of the award 
Directors | Report on form P11D, section A | Class 1A National Insurance on the full value of the award

##Readily convertible assets (RCAs)

If you award an [RCA](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/payroll/special-pay/non-cash.htm "RCA"){:rel="external"} to an employee with at least 20 years service and no previous award in the last 10 years:

* add any value above £50 per year of service to your employee’s earnings
* deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance and PAYE tax through payroll

For all other employees:

* add the total value to your employee’s earnings
* deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance and PAYE tax through payroll

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[RCAs]:readily convertible assets
*[RCA]:readily convertible asset
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
